A Susquehanna/WHTM-TV poll released Thursday showed McGinty leading Toomey by 6 points, with a 47-41 margin. 
In a CNN poll also released Thursday, McGinty led Toomey by 5 points. 
On Wednesday, a Monmouth poll found that McGinty held a 3-point lead. 
RealClearPolitics' polling average currently shows McGinty leading Toomey by a 4.5 percent. FiveThirtyEight, which uses a much more complex set of calculations, gives McGinty a 75 percent chance of winning using its polls-only model.
(Pennlive.com)
I believe the polls in this case is moving towards the Republican incumbent pushed by further movement of Trump.

Though race is close to dead even in most polls of the past week, with McGinty only holding slight edge, Democrats superior GOTV efforts and top of the ticket last minute push Monday should cushion her lead.
Latest polls show McGinty with a consistent (although narrow) lead.

538 giving Toomey's opponent, McGinty a 72.9% prob of winning: http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2016-election-forecast/senate/pennsylvania/ Here are the latest campaign fundraising numbers:

Toomey's waffling over Trump, along with general disgust regarding Trump's comments about grabbing women will doom both of them. McGinty has been surprisingly unflappable & made a good showing in debate. Toomey's also waving around weak, 1-time support of a background check bill as "proof" of his "ability of work with both parties" when he's actually been a consistent hard-right voter & NRA supporter. Phila. suburbs are not the comfortable Republican "country club" conservatives they once were & women vote more than men. Hard to believe, but I think he'll actually lose this time.
Weak Democratic opponent is the only reason he wins.
Melanie's speech wasn't soon enough or significant enough to bump Toomey's chances.
Clinton's extremely likely win in Pennsylvania and Toomey's rightward lean in a left-leaning state will do him in during a presidential election level turnout of 58-63 percent.
Clinton is still significantly ahead in Pa and I expect there to be coat tails which will lead to a loss by Toomey.

An Incumbent has a great deal of leverage in most elections. Certainly in congressional elections that is true. Senatorial races run almost like national races. Based on Likely Voter surveys I believe that McGinty has a chance. But, politics is fickle and the elections are a long way off - in a 24-hour news cycle. I'll give McGinty the advantage in the race for now. But, she needs to raise more money, and hope for a mistake on Toomey's part.

Gabby Giffords just endorsed him (after he broke from the gun lobby and is supporting a bill "to help prevent felons, domestic abusers and the dangerously mentally ill from obtaining firearms at gun shows and online") Toomey narrowly trailing Democratic challenger Katie McGinty in the latest Quinnipiac University poll.  Read more: http://www.politico.com/story/2016/08/gabby-giffords-pac-endorses-pat-toomey-mark-kirk-227268#ixzz4IBcjmpK2

The historical average probability of a Senate incumbent winning reelection is 80%+ and even in the Reagan wave, it was still 55%.  The current polls showing McGinty in the lead are within the margin of error, so while I do ascribe some informational content there, I think summer polls are less informative vs. fall polls Per the Federal Election Commission (FEC), Toomey has more money vs. McGinty ($7.7MM vs. $2.4MM) despite spending more ($12.0MM vs $4.4MM) and it seems like the RNC is going to divert more funds to its down ticket races.  For the approx. 10% undecided voters, I think name recognition / inertia and expected higher media spending favor Toomey.  Also, the latest stories indicate that more voters are registering Republican vs. Democrat in Pennsylvania, which is another point for Toomey Pennsylvania unemployment has also tracked below the national average, which I think is another positive for Toomey.  Finally, I think Toomey distancing himself from Trump and his stance on gun control is likely to widen his appeal with independents The most important thing is to watch fundraising and how polls start trending starting in Sept. https://www.opensecrets.org/overview/reelect.php http://www.fec.gov/fecviewer/CandidateCommitteeDetail.do https://fred.stlouisfed.org/graph/?g=6IQZ

Recent polls show McGinty with around a 2% lead, which is only slightly better than a coin flip.  Being in a relatively blue state where Clinton has a pretty good lead in polling should be helpful--Democratic turnout is likely to be higher than Republican turnout.

McGinty is currently up 2.6% based on polling averages. Toomey was once heavy favorite, but hasn't been consistently winning in the polls since June/early July. Toomey has not endorsed Trump but has not distanced himself to the degree of the NeverTrump movement, nor has he disavowed him. Trump is currently polling at 37.5% and is behind 8.7 to Clinton in PA. Trump has only a 14.7% chance to win PA based on fivethirtyeight's polls only forecast. Toomey seems to have two disadvantages, as I see it. If polling trends more towards Clinton in the presidential race, Toomey could be susceptible to Republicans staying at home on election day because of a possible landslide presidential election. However, this is likely mitigated somewhat due to PA's Eastern Time Zone location and the voting block voting before election results are in. Toomey also faces the problem of having to count on many Hilary and third party voting to vote across the ticket in order to win. Split ticket voting is down significantly, particularly in the 2012 election, according to the Washington Post. However, there is a chance that Toomey severed himself from Trump and/or Trump makes strides to tone down his rhetoric under his new campaign structure. This would likely improve his chances somewhat, although the effect is unknown given that Mark Kirk has not seen a substantial bump singing rescinding his Trump endorsement.

According to Real Clear Politics,  Senator Toomey is currently losing ground to challenger McGinty and this has not changed since August 7.  And as has previously been said, there are more Democrat than Republican voters in Pennsylvania by a long ton.   http://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2016/senate/pa/pennsylvania_senate_toomey_vs_mcginty-5074.html

Democrats outnumber Republicans in the state by a million voters. Pennsylvania consistently votes Democratic in presidential elections.  No Republican presidential candidate has carried Pennsylvania since the 1980's.

'The gender and racial gaps are wide in the Pennsylvania Senate race. Women back
Democratic challenger Katie McGinty 52 – 38 percent, while men back Republican incumbent
Sen. Pat Toomey 51 – 41 percent. White voters go 51 percent for Toomey and 42 percent for McGinty. Non-white voters go Democratic 71 – 12 percent.'
http://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2016/senate/pa/pennsylvania_senate_toomey_vs_mcginty-5074.html

http://www.nbcnews.com/politics/2016-election/ticket-splitters-could-be-key-vulnerable-gop-senate-incumbents-n633751 " Pat Toomey . . . hasn't announced whether he will vote for the GOP nominee. The latest NBC News/Wall Street Journal/Marist Poll has Trump down 9 points in Pennsylvania and Toomey is down 4 points in his race against former state environmental official Katie McGinty. That would suggest that Toomey should run away from Trump. "But Pennsylvania is a complicated state full of a key Trump demographic group, whites with less than a bachelor's degree. In 2012, those voters made up 34% of the total electorate and they are crucial for Republican candidates in the state. They make up a lot of the GOP vote in the central and western parts of the state (in the western half of the state only two counties are above the national average for having at least a bachelor's degree). Meanwhile the southeastern corner around Philadelphia is better educated (four densely populated counties above the national average on college degrees) and strongly opposed to Trump. "Toomey has to be careful not to support Trump too much for fear alienating suburban Philly, but he also has to be careful not to dump Trump because of those Trump bases of support elsewhere. 
~~~~~~~
http://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2016/senate/pa/pennsylvania_senate_toomey_vs_mcginty-5074.html Since early July the polls have flipped from Toomey up as much as 10%, to McGinty up as much as 7%, with McGinty currently averaging up 2.6%
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  Momentum is with Clinton and McGinty.   Opinions are shaping and hardening.  The closer the election is, the harder it is to change the direction of the momentum.
If Hillary still runs, McGinty wins.
HRC has Pennsylvania in bag. Trump and therefore Toomey can't make a comeback.
Pat Toomey will be able to separate himself from Donald Trump
Clinton will win state- Toomey can't run that far ahead

Trump may not get all of the GOP voters to sign on, however, enough will split tickets or come out and vote the Senate race to let him slip in.  If the election is felt to be over for president the voter turn out will be much lower than in a close Presidential race and the will help Toomey. And of course he is the incumbent.

Harry Enten, in fivethirtyeight.com, writes about the drag that Trump's low poll numbers are having on Republican candidates for the Senate: Republicans have also seen their prospects worsen in Pennsylvania. Trump is now down 10 percentage points in the state, a headwind that may be too much for Republican Sen. Pat Toomey to overcome. Toomey, like Ayotte, had been leading in most polls before the conventions. But he has trailed in four of the five polls conducted since the conventions. Toomey’s slide, in particular, should worry Republicans. He has made it clear that he is not a Trump fan and has avoided appearing with Trump when he visits the Keystone State. And yet, their fates still seem tied. It may be that down-ballot Republicans can only do so much to keep themselves from getting swept up in an anti-Trump tide.

Assuming that Toomey will get some of the  Koch network bongo buck being doled out after "Labor" Day and his campaign has smarts to put Katie McGinty on the defensive, linking her and the Dems to the political culture that produced now convicted former attorney general Kathleen Kane,  stuff Kane did like  perjury, criminal conspiracy, jury tampering, (the once rising Pennsyltucky Dem star, is now convicted criminal- guilty on all counts)- then McGinty has big problems.
